page.title: 09IN LIVING MEMORY
page.content: 20 RESIDENTS OF MANY YEARS STANDING WERE INTERVIEWED. 8 WERE OVER 80 YEARS OLD, (THE OLDEST 93). LIVING THROUGH TIMES OF GREAT CHANGES LEFT THEM SORRY ABOUT THE EFFECTS THE CHANGES HAVE HAD UPON THE LOCALITY. RAPID INCREASES IN NUMBERS OF HOMES AND PEOPLE LEFT THEM REGRETTING THE LOSS OF CLOSE COMMUNITY LIFE WHEN THE VILLAGES WERE ALMOST SELF SUFFICIENT FOR SHOPPING WORK AND FUN. MONEY WAS SHORT, HOUSEWORK HARD AND ENTERTAINMENT SELF MADE. TRIPS TO NORWICH, OFTEN ON FOOT, WERE RARE. THE ARRIVAL OF MAINS POWER, WATER AND DRAINS WAS WELCOME BUT AT A COST, IN THAT IT HELPED GROWTH. THE GENERAL FEELING OF THE ELDERLY RESIDENTS OF THE VILLAGE WAS SUMMED UP BY ONE, "WHEN YOU WERE YOUNG YOU KNEW EVERYONE, NOW YOU DON'T HARDLY KNOW ANYBODY."
